values:
Dar, Seiryu, and August leaned against trees as Meis and Cross paced uneasily in front of them. The briefing was done, so nothing needed to be said. The anxiety in the air was palpable.

The tension broke like an old bowstring when Cailyn dropped out of a tree in the middle of the crowd.

“They’re off safe,” she said. “All of them.”

“Any indication where they’re headed?” Cross continued to pace.

Cailyn swallowed, and looked at the trees around her as if to draw a bit of strength. “South.”

Cross sighed. “We know they’re headed south. Anything more specific?”

“South to Dorman’s Folly.”

Cross and Meis narrowed their eyes in disbelief. Dar grunted, and August whistled. Only Seiryu gave no sign of recognition. “Is that.. bad?”

“Maybe,” August said in his typically laconic way. “Maybe not.”

“The Folly’s a ghost town,” Dar said. “Dried up, nothing left. It’s been deserted for hundreds… thousands… of years.”

“Despite people’s best efforts,” Meis said. “Bandits and highwaymen and the like have tried to use it as a safe zone or hiding spot, but either they died there or they’ve been very secretive because I’ve never heard of any of them coming back.”

“In short,” Cross said, “Either they’re going to have to deal with a bandit hideout that’s been hidden for fifty years, or whatever presence killed the village that was there to begin with.”

“Or neither of those things,” finished Dar, “because who knows with rumors anyway?”

Seiryu nodded. “Ghost town. Right.”

“I don’t know why  they’ve chosen that, though,” Cailyn muttered. “Doesn’t make any sense. Why would they pick that spot instead of somewhere more… inviting?”

“No choice,” Cross realized. “Can you think of anywhere else in the forest that they’d consider themselves safe from the forces without? Dormand’s Folly has a reputation, and—as much of a last-ditch effort as this is—that reputation can work in their favor.”

“Not only that,” Meis continued. “But we have to make sure they’re safe from the forces behind us, too. This may not have been their best plan.”

“And ensure their security.” Cross scratched at his goatee in a rare moment of flatfooted vulnerablity, a few curly red hairs coming out and spiraling invisibly to the ground. “Which means that we either have to kill the invading force, or misdirect them away from the abandoned village.”

“But if there really is something dangerous in Dorman’s Folly, we can’t let them just walk in.” August took a sip of tea, from a cup that he had apparently summoned out of nowhere. “So do we trail them? Lead them? Give them a miss entirely and just misdirect the attacking troops?”

“And we don’t have sufficient forces to spare for any sort of splitting up,” said Seiryu. “It’s together or die.”

“Maybe… not.” Meis ducked behind a nearby tree. “There’s lots of cover in here,” came his voice from behind. “If we can hide… abandon the battle strategies that the Samaelian military drilled into our heads in command school… then splitting up can still work.”

“Ahhh… Street thuggery.” Dar cracked his knuckles. “Now this, I’m comfortable with.”

“Dar, my friend,” August said as he beaned him over the head lightly with the teacup, “this is forest thuggery. Although I’m sure the principles are the same. I think I’m sufficiently flexible in mind and blade to pull off this sort of guerrilla work.” August put his tea away. “So I take it we’re going for defeat of their forces, rather than misdirection?”

“If the good people of the village have no choice but to turn to a ghost town for their self-preservation, perhaps we have no choice but to resort to uneven warfare to protect them,” said Meis. “If that means killing Samaelian soldiers…”

“I wish we could tell who’s really bought into their lies, and who could be convinced not to attack… or even join our cause.” Seiryu polished his sword absentmindedly. “Attacking indiscriminately just isn’t like us.”

“It might have to become like us. And we can’t second-guess our foes, either.” Cross sighed. “All we can hope is that they’ve been informed of the atrocities we were ordered to commit… and, knowing that, are attacking of their own free will.”

“What free will?” Dar quipped. “This is the military.”

There were a few tense laughs. Cross cleared his throat.
“So, now that we’re all up to speed, let’s catch up with Ms. Denen and her crew. They’re waiting for us.”
I intend to start writing a smidgen of flash fiction here on my LJ at some point.
I'm exhausted, but now I'm finally a little bit ahead on homework. Maybe I can reward myself by writing some, I dunno.
Rain outside. It's pretty cool, I guess, even though I'm not really a rain sort of person.
Probably going to start on some pancakes before Emma gets up.

I rearranged my bookmarks today.
Oh, and school started today, but that's not really that important, is it?
Ha ha ha. Okay, seriously. First day of school went pretty well. Four math classes in a row gives me a tad of fatigue, but I think overall it'll be worth it.
I should have gotten up about... four hours earlier. Now I have to restart my sleep schedule more quickly, and that's not gonna be easy.
A bunch of my friends recently got Twitter accounts. Hooray! Maybe I can convince more people to get some.

I'm helping Emma stitch together her latest cosplay outfit, while simultaneously planning my own and fulfilling my New Year's Resolution goal of 10000 words of fiction output per month. Also, need to start blogging more.

Going to the DOMA protest rally tomorrow. There will, apparently, be counter-protesters there.
BRING IT ON.

I just got back from Emma's birthday party. Yes, over a month late.
I got to see Yuhong again--maybe for the last time in a long time. :-(

The semester of doom is finally over, with the completion of my two last finals.
Hurray! Huzzah! And such celebratory things.
It was an interesting time though. Living with Emma, finally choosing a direction for my education, getting more involved in the LGBTQ coalition... Writing my second novel... And getting thrashed by physics.
Well, the good stuff will go on and the bad stuff is behind me. I'm feeling pretty optimistic.
I'm going to go write some o' my novel now.
I saw it. And it was... It was beyond amazing. I can't really say much else, besides that I definitely want to go see it again sometime, and get it if it comes out on DVD.
Gah. Just... Gaaaah. Tests are UNFORTUNATE.

I have two big tests tomorrow. I... I want to cry. ;_;

I'll post about how it goes.

Emma and I hung out with Fred tonight and had a great time. We also got to meet one of Fred's friends, who is also awesome.
So I'm in a pretty good mood. Time to get cracking on my programming for math!

I was feeling glummer and glummer today, and I didn't really understand why until someone said I looked younger than I was.

When I was a kid, I was told that maturity was great. I'd be able to overcome my ADD on my own! I'd be able to relate to people! I'd be able to actually get things done!

I'd... I'd... Well, damn.

And it feels like none of it ever happened. I feel like a three-year old... a really distractible three-year-old... forced to live as an adult. I still can't pay attention. I still can't function properly in public. I still do incredibly stupid things with no rhyme or reason, with no self-control and no way to monitor myself.

As if to warn people of my roiling immaturity, I even look younger than I am. I'm keeping my hair short and wearing a chinbeard just to keep people from thinking I'm twelve years old. From the way I act all the time, I don't blame them a bit.

And the consequences for my intractable, unwanted inner youth are getting steeper. I'm getting married, for God's sake! This can't go on. But it does, despite my best efforts. My periods of actual maturity, of self-discipline and self-control, are infrequent and fleeting.

I wish I could just grow up.

I'm working on learning how to use the symbolic algebra program Maxima. It's pretty nice, and free. I'd probably use the more supported Mathematica or Maple, but (as Coach Z said) I can't afford the moneycost variety.

So far, I've gotten it to solve differential equations, which will be pretty nice if I take that class again.

Lots of homework over the course of the day, and some minor mental breakdowns over revelations of certain physics grades, but otherwise I'm frosty.
It was World Aids Day so I went out to Hayden Lawn and there was an event.
Check it out, y'all biscuitheads.

It's Thanksgiving, so we spent the day with family friends of ours. I actually didn't eat all that much, but I got full anyway.
I'm thankful for a lot of things, but I don't really believe they all need to be broadcasted in public.
Happy T!

It feels good to get involved in a cause. Emma and I tabled today for the LGBTQ Coalition on campus, and we're doing some stuff for Transgender Day of Remembrance... It's nice not to be quite so wrapped up in myself.
Trip went well. I got a lot of writing done, and EMMA PASSED! ^_^
Eggnog got spilled on the couch. Blah!

I got some extra exercise today, playing Bocce with Emma. We had a picnic lunch out in the greenbelt on our picnic blanket, then played several rounds of bocce. Fun!
(We tied.)

I have the day off! So, I'm gonna
a) kick ass novel-wise
b) do some errands
c) maybe meet up with a friend?
I dunno. Lots of options!
I am officially on track with NaNoWriMo again. Hooray!

Getting caught up on wordcount, spending some time with Emma tonight, cooking dinner... life is pretty good. If it weren't for nagging doubts about fading liberties in the wake of the election, I'd be feeling awesome!
...aww, I just got myself kinda depressed again. O.o

Had a great write-in today at Bookman's. Pretty productive. I'm almost caught up!
And I get to see Emma again tonight, woo!

Got quite a bit of writing done today. I managed to ALMOST get caught up in wordcount. Also, I worked on my MAT300 final papers.
But negatively, I dinged my laptop screen. :-(

Went to the LGBTQ Coalition meeting today. It was awesome. Tensions were running high, but only because voters in America are... well, yeah.
Anyway.

It's pretty nice outside. Emma and I might play some bocce or something, maybe go to a club meeting later.
woo!
My post-election low spirits got perked up today 'cause I got to spend a few hours with a friend I haven't seen in months. Yay!

Okay, so Obama won. Fine, whatever.
The problem is the other things that were being voted in while everyone was focused on the Presidential election.
AZ-102 passed.
FL-2 passed.
The Arkansas gay adoption ban passed.
And most horrifyingly of all, CA-8 passed, rendering thousands of legal same-sex marriages null and void.
The cause of freedom took four huge steps backwards yesterday. We're going to look back on this day in shame. Just like we see "Whites Only" bathrooms and cringe, we're going to see "straight only" marriage as a historical embarrassment.

Heavy hw day. Fortunately, technically I could not write today AT ALL and still be on track.
So yeah! Rad.
Little more than 2500 words under my belt. Busy day today, but hopefully I can break 5000 by today? Hope?

Went to the Prop 102 panel. It was really interesting to see the two groups communicating, but ultimately it was like everyone was trying to set everyone else on fire with their minds.
The three anti-102 panelists were rad, though. The fact that there was an actual LGBTQ person on the panel seemed to really unnerve two of the three pro-102 panelists, as did the fact that Neal Lester kept alluding to the parallels between the racial civil rights movement and the sexual civil rights movement. As did, for that matter, the fact that there was a very well-prepared cultural anthropologist on the left side of the table.
Body language is a funny thing.

Physics lab was easier than usual today.
Gonna go take a shower and get ready to go to the Prop 102 debate they're holding today.
NO ON 102!

I have a thousand stories buzzing in my head right now.
One, my novel.
Two, my WoD game. Had some good ideas for that earlier today.
Three, another thing I've been working on that has yet to come to fruition.
Four through 1000: other things. Like Calmar, and my urban fantasy ideas...

Just watched the latest episode.
My thoughts:

YEAH! GO MATT! Brain-mojo ftw!
Sylar, you're either an idiot or a master strategist. I can't tell which.
Mohinder, what the hell.
Arthur is killing off season 2's villains like he had a personal grudge. I wonder if there's a writer on board there?
Peter, this is the first step you have to being less than a total idiot. Don't screw it up.
Nathan? Dude? Enthusiasm is great, but you gonna get yo'self killed.
And finally... Daphne, Matt can STILL READ YOUR MIND. Why are you trying to play him? Whose side are you on?

That's kinda cute. They dressed the site up for Halloween.
Wait... What's that? Over there?
Oh God.
Don't come near me.
DON'T COME ANY CLOSER
OH GOD
AHHHHH
.......
BRAAAAAAIIIIIIIIIIINS
Today is my "hell day". I've got too much going on, to be honest. -_-

I just went to the NaNoWriMo East Valley Kickoff. It was a truly astounding, possibly illegal, amount of fun.
These people are going to be great to have nanovel-writing fun with!

Emma and I just watched The Fifth Element. First time for her, first time in a while for me. It's a good movie!
Any commentary on the infamous bandage scene is hereby elided.

Wedding plans continue apace. Most likely gonna be February 14th, 2010.
Renaissance ho!

I wish I had the social skills to politely tell someone that I do not know them well enough to want to go to their birthday party, thank you very much, and I have stuff to do that day anyway. Without sounding like an asshole.
Usually I'd just make up s

Turns out, unannounced save a small note in a huge wall of text in the syllabus, that my music test ended earlier than I thought it did, and I thus missed it entirely. The screaming and crying is over, and now I'm just dreading having to retake it next semester in the middle of an even more massive course load.
